Fig. 1 Experimental setup for catalytic studies. Each gas is delivered through mass flow controllers (MFCs not shown). Water was vaporized in the hot zone and carried by flowing N2. The generated elemental sulfur was captured in a sulfur trap at 150 °C. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Experiment setup for CS2 breakthrough. P2O5 traps were used to remove moisture from the gas stream prior to entering the mass flow controllers and then into the adsorption system within a GC oven. Two pressure gauges were used to monitor the pressure. The 4-port valve was used to deliver either feed or purge gas into the adsorption cell. The gas stream after the cell was sent to a mass-spec system for analysis. A needle valve was used to balance the pressure within the system and a check valve was installed for preventing backflow. Graphical abstract Destruction of CS2 in the modified Claus process plays a vital role in achieving high sulfur recovery (>99.9%). Although it has lower catalytic activity for CS2 hydrolysis than titania, alumina has been widely used in Claus plants for conversion of sulfur species into elemental sulfur, because it is less expensive, highly active for the Claus reaction and mechanically robust. This research explores improving CS2 hydrolysis on Claus alumina catalyst by modification with 1 wt.% of either CuO, TiO2, Fe2O3, Co2O3, Sc2O3 or Na2O. These modified catalysts were tested using the first catalytic convertor conditions. While catalyst impregnation with most of the metals described above leads to minor improved CS2 conversion, the deposition of both Cu2+ and Ti4+ stood out for resulting 22.6 and 33.7% higher activity, respectively. Results suggest that the improved catalytic activity can be explained by reduced hydrophilicity (increased hydroxyl dispersion) and somewhat increased basicity on the surface of the catalysts. Keywords Claus catalyst Alumina Transition metal oxides, carbon disulfide hydrolysis sulfur recovery sulfur dioxide emissions 1 Introduction The Claus process is widely used to convert hydrogen sulfide to elemental sulfur, thereby lowering sulfur concentrations in hydrocarbon feedstocks and increasing the availability of elemental sulfur primarily used for processing fertilizers [1,2]. Currently, the two primary Claus catalysts used in industry are alumina and titania (Al2O3 and TiO2). Both perform very well for catalyzing the Claus reaction (Reaction 1), but differ in their activity for other ancillary recovery reactions. (1) 2 H2S + SO2⇌3/8 S8 + 2 H2O Compared to TiO2, Al2O3 is less effective for the necessary destruction of carbon disulfide (CS2) and carbonyl sulfide (COS) [3,4]. Inefficient destruction of these species within the catalytic stages of a sulfur recovery unit (SRU), can significantly impact total sulfur recoveries. However, this aspect of alumina has not kept it from dominating the Claus catalyst market, primarily because it is less expensive and can be used in split-bed applications with titania. A catalytic converter entirely composed of TiO2 is not typically necessary to bring CS2 and COS down to manageable levels for the tail gas treatment unit. From a material science perspective, alumina exhibits a higher mechanical and thermal stability than titania. This stability is an important requirement for a Claus catalyst to maintain its manipulated porous structure, because of potential fouling by liquid sulfur and harsh high-water vapor conditions (> 30 mol.% at 260–320 °C). For these reasons, this research is dedicated to investigating new Claus catalysts on the basis of an alumina support material. Both morphology and chemical properties should be considered for any applicable Claus catalyst [5,6]. Catalyst morphology, such as particle size and pore size, not only affects mass transfer but may also cause capillary condensation of species such as sulfur or water vapor. Catalytic performance is known to improve by introducing meso- and macropores within catalyst pellets, which has been achieved by the catalyst manufacturers [7]. In addition to morphology, the chemical properties of Claus catalysts are also essential for the conversion of sulfur compounds. The reaction between H2S and SO2 (Reaction 1) readily achieves equilibrium both on titania and alumina, but under industrial conditions, the destructions of CS2 and COS are kinetically limited. Where COS is easier to react than CS2 [8], CS2 conversion has been widely used as a benchmark for evaluating different Claus catalyst materials. Among the two CS2 destruction reactions, the hydrolysis route is considered to be dominant (Eq.2 and 3) [9]. (2) C S 2 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( g ) ⇌ 2 H 2 S ( g ) + C O 2 ( g ) Δ H ° = − 67.95 k J m o l − 1 (3) C S 2 ( g ) + S O 2 ( g ) ⇌ 3 / 8 S 8 ( g ) + C O 2 ( g ) Δ H ° = − 52.46 k J m o l − 1 The chemisorbed water in the form of hydroxyl groups (−OH) on the catalyst surface is widely accepted to be the active sites for CS2 and COS hydrolysis reactions [6]. There are many types of −OH groups on γ–Al2O3 [10], with an −OH surface occupation of up to 60% at 300 °C [11]. The hydroxyl groups have been widely studied for both Bronsted and Lewis acidity; however, it has been found that the basicity is relevant to the CS2 conversion [12]. It has been reported that the basicity of Al2O3 was increased by addition of alkaline metal oxides [13,14]. However, the advantage of increased basicity by addition of the alkaline metal may be offset by extraneous hydrophilicity (i.e., too many −OH groups), because water is known to compete with CS2 for the −OH active sites at these conditions [6]. Our recent research showed that the decoration of TiO2 with transition metal oxides lead to an increase in −OH active sites, yet improved catalytic activity [15]. Therefore, our approach in this research was to promote the activity of a commercial Claus Al2O3 catalyst by decoration of the alumina surface with various transition metal oxides. The transition metals were selected to have multiple oxidation states in order to facilitate better electron transfer which is believed to aid in reducing extraneous surface sulfate [16]. In order to reduce the cost, relatively inexpensive and widely available metal species were selected, i.e., Cu2+, Fe3+, Ti4+, Sc3+, and Co2+. They have multiple oxidations states, which facilitates reducing sulfate formation [17]. The prepared catalysts were evaluated at T = 300 and 260 °C and the experimental sulfur conversions were compared to calculated equilibrium conversions. Additionally, in order to understand the catalytic performance, the catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, CO2, water and hexafluoro-isopropanol adsorption, CS2 breakthrough, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and ionic chromatography (IC) analysis. 2 Methods Safety notes: because this research involved the use of toxic gases H2S and SO2, all catalytic tests were conducted in a walk-in cabinet equipped with high-velocity ventilation, permanent gas detectors and a caustic scrubbing system. The detectors are interfaced with solenoids controlling air operated valves to allow (air on) gas flow from another isolated and ventilated storage cabinet. In the case of a leak leading to toxic gas concentrations exceeding 10ppmv H2S or 5 ppmv SO2, the air operated valves would shut down all toxic gas flow. 2.1 Materials 98% Cu(NO3)2‧2.5H2O, 99.9% Sc(NO3)3, 98% Fe(NO3)3‧9H2O, 98% Co(NO3)2‧6H2O, 99% NaNO3, 97% Ti(O i Pr)4 and 99% CS2 were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and used without further purification. H2S, SO2, CO2, N2 and helium were purchased from Praxair (Canada) with a purity of 99.999%, except H2S and SO2 with a purity of 99.6% and 99.98%, respectively. 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts Using a typical catalyst impregnation methodology, into 40 ml of deionized water was added the calculated amount of a metal nitrate containing 1.00 g of the metal. The resulting solution was added into a beaker that contained 100 g of γ-alumina under stirring, and the mixture was heated in an oven at 50 °C for 4 h. After 16 h of drying at 100 °C under vacuum, the catalysts were calcined at 400 °C for 2 h. The resulting materials were labeled as 1 wt % M/Al2O3, where M stands for the metal cation species: Cu2+, Fe3+, Ti4+, Sc3+, Co2+ and Na+. Using the same method, 0.5 and 2 wt % Cu/Al2O3 catalysts were also synthesized. 1 wt % TiO2 xerogel modified alumina was synthesized differently using a sol − gel self-assembly method [18,19]. As described previously, 100 g of γ-alumina was submerged in 250 ml of 0.5 M NaOH(aq) solution overnight, followed by 16 h of drying at 80 °C under vacuum. The alkaline-treated alumina was added to 100 ml of heptane, followed by the addition of 6.10 g Ti(O i Pr)4 (21 mmol) and 1.68 g of acetic acid (27.3 mmol). After 10 min of gentle mixing, an additional 7.79 g of acetic acid (126 mmol) was added under stirring and the mixture was heated to 60 °C. After 2 days of gelation and aging, the resulting material was dried for 16 h at 80 °C, followed by calcination for 2 h at 400 °C. The resulting material was labeled as 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3. The feed gases were delivered by means of mass flow controllers (Brooks 5850 E series) and a control module (Model FM4600A, Advanced Specialty Gas Equipment) after filtration (5 μm, Swagelok). Then the sample was exposed to a 16% hexafluoro‒isopropanol stream at 150 °C for 2 h. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalysis studies At 300 °C and a space velocity of 1000 h−1, typical first convertor conditions in the Claus plant, all of the modified catalysts performed better than the non-modified commercial alumina. The CS2 conversions (Fig. 3 a, blue columns) followed a trend of 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3, 1%Cu2+/Al2O3> 1%Co2+/Al2O3, 1%Fe3+/Al2O3, 1%Ti4+/Al2O3, 1%Sc3+/Al2O3> 1%Na+/Al2O3> Al2O3. 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 and 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 were two catalysts that stood out for their ca. 20% better CS2 conversion than the commercial Al2O3. The fibrous TiO2 xerogel (1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3) synthesized via the sol-gel process exhibited a better activity than the TiO2 derived from impregnation via TiOSO4 (1%Ti4+/Al2O3). This implies that the CS2 catalytic activity trend observed was related to both physical and chemical properties of the transition metal oxides, which is discussed in more detail below. Lastly, transition metals appear to be better catalyst promoters than alkaline metals for CS2 conversion. It has been mentioned earlier that the Al2O3 already contains Na+, so it was interesting to see that the addition of 1% more Na+ still increased CS2 conversion by ca. 5%. This is in line with previous observation [23,24]; however, this activity increment diminished at a lower reaction temperature and a higher space velocity. When the reaction temperature was decreased to 260 °C, CS2 conversions decreased significantly for all catalysts (Fig. 3b). It is noted that the reaction of H2S and SO2 is exothermic and its equilibrium is favored by a lower temperature, hence more sulfur is produced at 260 °C than at 300 °C. While 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 and 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 still showed 18% and 20% higher catalytic activity respectively than the non-modified Al2O3 (Fig. 3b, blue columns) at 260 °C, other modified catalysts had similar or only moderately improved CS2 conversion when compared to the non-modified Al2O3. It was anticipated that the modified catalysts had a smaller pore size after the deposition of secondary metal oxides, as discussed in the N2 physisorption section, which may affect the catalytic performance. The CS2 conversion was also a function of space velocity. From Fig. 3 it can be seen that all CS2 conversions decreased when the space velocity increases from 1000 to 1440 h−1. To determine if the reaction kinetics was affected by mass transfer diffusion, we calculated the Weisz‒Prater (Cwp  = 0.047) and Reynolds numbers (Re = 53) at 300 °C and 1000 h-1 (see Supplementary Information). Because Cwp was less than 0.3, the reaction rate was not limited by the internal diffusion within the porous catalyst beads. The external diffusivity (89 cm2 s−1) was significantly higher than the internal diffusivity (0.0082 cm2 s−1) and the flow within the catalyst bed was in the transitional region (2000 > Re > 10); therefore, the reaction rate was not limited by the external diffusion either [21]. Thus, we believe that the CS2 conversion was dominated by chemical reaction kinetics. Because the Cu2+ modified Al2O3 looked promising from both catalytic and synthetic perspectives, 0.5% and 2% Cu2+ modified Al2O3 were also synthesized and tested for CS2 conversion. As shown in Fig. 4 , at 300 °C and low space velocity (1000 h−1), 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 was still superior. However, at a lower temperature and higher space velocity, 0.5%Cu2+/Al2O3 showed a higher activity among the three catalysts. The CS2 conversion seemed to be related to the deposited amount of Cu2+, and the latter affected the porosity of the catalysts as described later. It should be noted that the above CS2 conversions were recorded at the reaction time of 4 h. Because all fresh catalysts had been aged with water vapor, H2S, and SO2 (for appropriate sulfation) before each test, a good Claus catalyst was supposed to have a stabilized performance, such as 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 (see SF1 in the Supplementary Information). The CS2 conversions often decline for most Claus catalysts with extraneous sulfate and coke accumulation. While most of H2S conversions of these catalysts were in line with the thermodynamic equilibrium, the catalytic activities of 1%Sc3+/Al2O3 and 1%Sc3+/Al2O3 were 14 and 12% lower, respectively (see SF2 in Supplementary Information). With the control experiments (a non-catalytic silica bed), no CS2 conversion was detected at both 260 and 300 °C based on GC detection limits for H2S and COS. While the scope of this research is limited to catalyst screening, a longer continuous reaction time would be necessary for long term industrial catalyst performance tests. In particular, large CS2 conversion differences between catalysts are much more prevalent at end-of-run conditions versus start-of-run here. 3.2 SEM As described earlier, the TiO2 xerogel (in 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3) was found to be the best catalyst for CS2 conversion at 300 °C and 1000 h−1. This could be attributed to the unique microstructure of the fibrous TiO2 on the surface of Al2O3, in addition to the fact that TiO2 is an inherently better catalyst for CS2 destruction. As shown in Fig. 5 a‒c, the Al2O3 pellet surface looks very rough and is composed of micrometer sized particles that are fused together. The irregularly shaped particles inevitably result in the macropores that are favorable for the CS2 conversion. However, these macropores do not provide as much surface area as mesopores. The fibrous microstructure of TiO2 can be observed at a higher magnification (Fig. 5d‒f). The size of the nanofibers was on the order of a few micrometres in length and 20 nm in diameter. Compared to Al2O3 in Fig. 5c, 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 in Fig. 5f shows a significantly higher porosity in the micron and submicron size due to observed empty spaces between the nanofibers. The high porosity generated by fibers only occurs on the Al2O3 pellet exterior surface, and there are no noticeable nanofibers found inside the pellets. The increased porosity, as shown in Fig. 5f, likely contributed to the activity for CS2 conversion (87.7% at 300 °C), given the fact that the alternative TiO2 impregnated form in 1%Ti4+/Al2O3 showed a much lower activity (72.9% at 300 °C). 3.3 N2 physisorption As shown in Table 2 , all tested catalysts exhibited relatively large pore sizes (5.5–6.7 nm) and high pore volumes (0.47‒0.56 cm3 g−1). After deposition of metal oxides on Al2O3, a decrease in surface area was observed for all catalysts, some as high as 20%; however, the change in pore volume did not follow the same trend, likely because the deposition occurred in the macropores and on the exterior surface of the catalyst pellets that were beyond the measurement limit of N2 physisorption range. The average mesopore size of the modified catalysts in Table 2 increased noticeably, although these might be misleading because a large range of pore sizes were included for the calculation of the average pore size. However, we note that calcination during catalyst preparation could also impact the results. An appropriate comparison would be to look at the BJH pore size distribution as shown in Fig. 6 , where various CuO loadings show a pore size change in the mesopore range for these catalysts. The unmodified Al2O3 exhibits the widest pore size distribution in the range of 2.4–5.2 nm. Compared to the unmodified Al2O3, Cu2+ loading caused the disappearance of smaller pores (ca. 2.7 nm). Further addition of Cu2+ from 0.5 to 2 wt.% resulted in a more uniform pore size by reducing the pore volumes of both large pores and small pores in the range of 2.5–5 nm. The spent catalysts were also analyzed with N2 physisorption and no catalyst displayed a significant mesopore change after testing under Claus conditions. Again, we recognize that we have not approached end-of-run conditions. 3.4 Powder XRD patterns The powder XRD patterns of all the fresh catalysts show that the main crystalline phase was γ-alumina, with a small amount of γ-boehmite (AlO(OH)) and gibbsite (Al(OH)3) crystallites. Both boehmite and gibbsite phases were more pronounced in all of the spent catalysts, possibly because they were exposed to a high concentration of water vapor in the reactor. Fig. 7 shows an example of 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 diffraction patterns for fresh and spent catalysts, which were comparable to that of other metal oxide modified Al2O3 (not shown). There was no sign of the secondary metal oxides in the XRD results, indicating that the crystallites were too small to show diffraction patterns [25]. A well distributed secondary metal oxide is an important feature, allowing a favorable long range intermolecular interactions as described in later sections. In addition, both 1%Co2+/Al2O3 and 1%Fe3+/Al2O3 turned black after they had been used, indicating that sulfidation had occurred. However, neither metal sulfides nor oxides could be found in the XRD results on the spent catalysts. 3.5 XPS analysis Table 3 shows the elemental concentrations obtained from XPS measurements of some fresh catalysts. It was observed that the Al2O3 contains sulfur (in the sulfate form) and sodium, while the modified Al2O3 samples had a small amount of nitrogen resulting from the incomplete decomposition of nitrate during the synthesis process. It should be noted that the XPS technique is limited to analysis of the top layers of solid samples; therefore, the concentrations of deposited materials can be overstated. The high-resolution scans in the O1s region of the XPS spectra revealed that more surface hydroxyl groups were present on Al2O3 after deposition of Ti4+ and Cu2+ (see Fig. 8 and Table 4 ). 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 exhibited the highest hydroxyl concentration in Table 4, which may explain why it was one of the best catalysts for CS2 destruction. The lattice hydroxyl group of gibbsite and boehmite phases can be detected for Al2O3 [26]; but these phases disappeared for the metal modified catalysts after calcination at 400 °C. As a result, there were no peaks assigned to the lattice hydroxyl groups in the modified alumina catalysts. Compared to 1%Ti4+/Al2O3, the 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 catalyst does not show much higher hydroxyl concentration even though NaOH was used to modify the Al2O3 surface. This was likely because some surface hydroxyl groups were consumed during the sol‒gel growth of TiO2 nanofibers on the Al2O3. Apparently, the hydroxyl groups on TiO2 surface cannot compensate the lost −OH on Al2O3. In fact, the amount of hydroxyl groups on 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 was not much higher than that of Al2O3 alone, even though the nanofibrous TiO2 modified Al2O3 shows the highest CS2 conversion. It seems that the morphology plays a more important role for CS2 conversion than the chemical properties when 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 and 1%Ti4+/Al2O3 are compared for their catalytic activity. 3.6 Sulfate content measured by IC Extraneous sulfate formation on Claus catalysts has been recognized as being responsible for a low CS2 conversion; however, a critical coverage of sulfate is necessary for Claus conversion. The latter is a significant reason why conventional TiO2 is more active for CS2 conversion. Addition of secondary metal oxides on Al2O3 introduces more hydroxyl groups, but it also makes the catalysts more vulnerable for increased surface sulfate (see Table 5 ). For all the catalysts modified with the transition metal oxides, the sulfate concentrations follow a trend of 1%Sc3+/Al2O3> 1%Fe3+/Al2O3> 1%Ti4+/Al2O3> 1%Co2+/Al2O3> 1%Cu2+/Al2O3. The higher sulfate of 1%Sc3+/Al2O3 should be related to the fact that there is only one oxidation state for Sc3+. Under the reducing environment in Claus converters, Fe3+, Ti4+ and Cu2+ can be partially reduced to Fe2+, Ti3+ and Cu+, respectively. These lower oxidation state species are believed to effectively reduce sulfate content [17]. On the basis of our results, this phenomenon was more pronounced on the Cu2+/Al2O3 catalysts. The low sulfate poisoning with the Cu2+ modified catalysts could contribute to their higher CS2 conversion. It was surprising to see that, although having the highest sulfate concentration, 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 still exhibited the highest CS2 conversion. As an alternative to the low-sulfate explanation on TiO2, using breakthrough experiments, Huisman and coworkers discovered that a significant amount of TiO2 was transformed into TiS2 by reacting with CS2 at 300 °C (Eq.7) [27]. TiS2 quickly reacts with water to produce H2S and TiO2 (Eq.8). This reaction route potentially makes TiO2 a better catalyst for CS2 conversion than Al2O3 at first Claus catalytic convertor conditions. Because TiS2 is produced only at a high temperature with CS2, and that TiS2 is very active with water, it has not been observed by others. (7) TiO2 + CS2 ⇌ TiS2 + CO2 ΔG = +21.07 kJ/mol (8) TiS2 + 2H2O ⇌ TiO2 + 2H2S ΔG = ‒37.29 kJ/mol The above TiO2 catalytic mechanism for CS2 conversion, however, does not seem to explain the 1%Ti4+/Al2O3 catalytic performance. 3.7 Basicity and hydrophilicity According to the XPS results, the amount of hydroxyl groups increased after modifying with transition metals on alumina; however, it was not clear to what extent the basicity increased, if at all. Previous reports have shown that, by addition of alkaline metal cation species on Al2O3, the basicity increased significantly, and the acidity was depressed [13]. The chemisorption occurred at the low adsorption coverage range (no more than 400 mmol g−1). In this study, basicity was studied using CO2 and hexafluoro-isopropanol adsorption. Fig. 9 shows the CO2 isotherms in the low adsorption coverage range where chemisorption occurs. The first few data points in the range of 10−6‒10-5 bar show that 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 had the highest amount of adsorbed CO2, indicating the highest basicity on the surface of this catalyst. The basicity of 1%Na+/Al2O3was slightly higher than 1%Ti4+/Al2O3 and Al2O3. The CO2 adsorption capacities on other modified Al2O3 were lower than that of Al2O3, suggesting that there was decreased basicity after deposition of the transition metal oxides (TiO2, Sc2O3, CoO and Fe2O3). These results are in line with the basicity of these metal oxides as shown in Table 6 except 1%Co2+/Al2O3[28]. CoO has a similar basicity as CuO; however, cobalt oxides are known to have oxidation state and phase transitions upon heating. Some CoO may have transformed to Co3O4 upon calcining in air during the synthesis process [29], and this would have reduced the basicity of this catalyst. It should be mentioned that, due to the reducing environment in the Claus reactor (contributed by the ca. 4–8% H2S), some metal cations can be reduced to a lower oxidation state. For example, Ti4+, Fe3+ and Cu2+ can be transformed partially to Ti3+, Fe2+ and Cu+, respectively. The reduced metal oxides in the Claus converter can reduce the basicity of the catalysts and increase the catalytic activity for CS2 conversion. Unfortunately, this phenomenon cannot be characterized by these CO2 adsorption experiments. In addition, the basicity of these catalysts may change due to high concentrations of water in the Claus convertors. The hexafluoro-isopropanol adsorption was performed after removal of impurities such as nitrate, carbonate and water from the surface at a temperature of 450 °C, saturating with water at 50 °C, followed by removal of excess water at 150 °C. These procedures allowed the catalyst surface to have more hydroxyl groups than after simple evacuation at 450 °C, and be more representative of Claus catalytic convertor conditions. As shown in Table 7 , the adsorption capacity of hexafluoro-isopropanolfollows a trend of 1%Na+/Al2O3> 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3> 1%Cu2+/Al2O3> Al2O3> 1%Ti4+/Al2O3> 1%Fe3+/Al2O3 = 1%Co2+/Al2O3> 1%Sc3+/Al2O3. While higher basicity can potentially promote CS2 conversion, it would unfortunately also increase sulfate. It is noted that 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 is fairly basic, but demonstrates a low surface −OH concentration according to XPS. In Table 7, the amount of adsorbed water at 50 °C was related to both the hydrophilicity and the porosity of the catalysts. Because the catalysts have similar porosity, the adsorbed water is most likely affected by hydrophilicity. The Al2O3 and 1%Na+/Al2O3 were apparently the most hydrophilic, and the Ti4+ modified catalysts showed the lowest hydrophilicity. The hydrophilicity follows a trend of 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3< 1%Ti4+/Al2O3 < 1%Cu2+/Al2O3< 1%Co2+/Al2O3< 1%Sc3+/Al2O3< 1%Fe3+/Al2O3< 1%Na+/Al2O3< Al2O3. At 150 °C, the amount of adsorbed water on each catalyst was in the same order of that of hexafluoro-isopropanol (Table 7), and they can be related to the water molecules interacting with the catalysts through dissociative adsorption [30]. The dissociative adsorption capacities of 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3, 1%Ti4+/Al2O3 and 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 were higher than that of Al2O3, in line with our XPS results as shown in Table 4. While the dissociated water might readily react with CS2, a higher hydrophilicity seems to have a negative effect on the performance of the catalyst. This was demonstrated by 1%Na+/Al2O3, which had a high capacity of chemisorbed water (highly hydrophilic) and the CS2 conversion was quite low among the tested catalysts. In contrast, all catalysts modified by transition metal oxides were less hydrophilic, which correlates to their better catalytic performance. As pointed out by other researchers, CS2 molecules are in competition for hydroxyl active sites with excess water in the Claus stream and the hydrophilic nature of the catalysts negatively affect the CS2 conversion [6]. Indeed, the competition from water molecules cannot be ignored, given the fact the water concentration is typically 300 times larger than that of CS2 in the first Claus catalytic convertor. Using the adsorption capacity of hexafluoro-isopropanol, the density of basic hydroxyl groups can be estimated, and the latter can be used to calculate TOF. Because the accurate reaction rates were not obtained as mentioned before, the TOFs were not calculated in this study. 3.8 CS2 adsorption capacity A typical breakthrough curve of CS2 (in black) on 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. 10 , where a CS2 breakthrough was detected by the mass spectrometer. CS2 breakthrough experiment results are listed in Table 8 . The samples of 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 and Al2O3 have very close CS2 adsorption capacities. 1%Cu2+/Al2O3 has a significantly lower CS2 adsorption capacity, even though it is among the most active catalysts for CS2 conversion. The adsorption of COS on the Lewis acid cites of a highly dehydroxylated Al2O3 has been observed by using FTIR [31]. The adsorbed CS2/COS could react with water, and this route has been proposed as the mechanism for CS2/COS hydrolysis [32]. However, in the first Claus catalytic converter, water/CS2 molar ratio is ca. 300, in addition to high concentrations of H2S, SO2 and elemental sulfur. There are therefore many competing species in addition to CS2/COS for the Al3+ and Ti3+/Ti4+ sites. Our CS2 breakthrough and catalytic results indicate that there was no correlation between CS2 adsorption capacity and CS2 conversion, which does not support the CS2‒Lewis acid mechanism. Instead, our new results agreed with the mechanism that CS2 interacts with the basic hydroxyl groups as the first step, which is supported by the in situ FTIR detection of hydro-thiocarbonate [33] and theoretical calculations. 4 Conclusions The catalytic activity of alumina can be improved significantly by simple impregnation with transition metal oxides, e.g., CuO, TiO2, Fe2O3, CoO, and Sc2O3. The promoted catalytic performance of the new catalysts for CS2 hydrolysis can mainly ascribed to the lower hydrophilicity. While increased basicity can lead to extraneous surface sulfate that can offset a better CS2 conversion, the multiple oxidation states offered by metal oxides can effectively mitigate sulfate formation. Both CuO and TiO2 xerogel modified commercial alumina showed significantly improved CS2 conversion under Claus catalytic converter conditions. The better performance of 1%Cu2+-x/Al2O3 can be attributed to both its high basicity and low hydrophilicity. The 1%Ti4+-x/Al2O3 had high macroporosity and low hydrophilicity. When considering the potential industrial applications, the 1% CuO modified Al2O3 would be more economical and therefore more viable for the catalyst manufactures; however, Cu catalysts can suffer from aging and end-of-run conditions need to be investigated. Our future work will include kinetics and more characterization studies of the best catalysts discovered in this study with the presence of benzene, toluene, and xylenes (BTXs). coredata.dc:description: Destruction of CS2 in the modified Claus process plays a vital role in achieving high sulfur recovery (>99.9%). Although it has lower catalytic activity for CS2 hydrolysis than titania, alumina has been widely used in Claus plants for conversion of sulfur species into elemental sulfur, because it is less expensive, highly active for the Claus reaction and mechanically robust. This research explores improving CS2 hydrolysis on Claus alumina catalyst by modification with 1 wt.% of either CuO, TiO2, Fe2O3, Co2O3, Sc2O3 or Na2O. These modified catalysts were tested using the first catalytic convertor conditions. While catalyst impregnation with most of the metals described above leads to minor improved CS2 conversion, the deposition of both Cu2+ and Ti4+ stood out for resulting 22.6 and 33.7% higher activity, respectively. Results suggest that the improved catalytic activity can be explained by reduced hydrophilicity (increased hydroxyl dispersion) and somewhat increased basicity on the surface of the catalysts.
